children.text: The brick cavity has been completed breached by the excessive build-up of mortar droppings down the back of the brickwork.
Part 3.3.5.6 Cavities of the NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA) requires that

‘The clear width of a cavity between the masonry veneer and the exterior face of the supporting frame must be not less than 25mm wide and where the masonry veneer is constructed on a slab-on-ground, the cavity must be drained to the outside’.
Additionally, Australian Standard AS 3700 Masonry Structures, requires in section 4.7 Prevention of Moisture Penetration, that

‘The cavities shall be free of obstruction that would allow moisture across the cavity, clean and continuous, and not bridged other than by ties or accessories, flashings, doors, windows, head jambs and sills’

‘The cavities shall be free of obstruction that would allow moisture across the cavity, clean and continuous, and not bridged other than by ties or accessories, flashings, doors, windows, head jambs and sills’.

All of this excessive mortar build-up will have to be removed from within the cavities, including in behind all of the plywood bracing panels, to stop the ability of the water and moisture that will collect within the cavity to transmit across onto the framework and also so that the flashings at the base of the walls can properly drain them as required by the Building Code of Australia (BCA) and AS 3700.
